standard_metadata.standard_description: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Equivalent ratios in the real world

question.content: Patrick's favorite shade of purple paint is made with $4$ milliliters of blue paint for every $3$ milliliters of red paint.    **Which of the following paint mixtures will create the same shade of purple?**

options.content: $3$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $4$ milliliters of red paint
$8$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $6$ milliliters of red paint
$6$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $8$ milliliters of red paint
$20$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $15$ milliliters of red paint
$12$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $16$ milliliters of red paint

hints.content: The paint mixture will create the same shade of purple if the ratio of blue to red paint is equivalent to $4 : 3$.

||| -|-|-|- Blue paint ($\text{mL}$) | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$ | $8$ Red paint ($\text{mL})$ | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$  | $6$  If the mixture has $2$ times as much blue paint, it also needs $2$ times as much red paint.  $8:6$ is equivalent to $4 : 3$.

||| -|-|-|- Blue paint ($\text{mL}$) | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$ | $20$ Red paint ($\text{mL})$ | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$  | $15$  If the mixture has $5$ times as much blue paint, it also needs $5$ times as much red paint.  $20:15$ is equivalent to $4 : 3$.

The following mixtures will create Patrick's favorite shade of purple:  - $8$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $6$ milliliters of red paint - $20$ milliliters of blue paint mixed with $15$ milliliters of red paint

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Super Salad Dressing is made with $8\text{ mL}$ of oil for every $3\text{ mL}$ of vinegar.    **Which of the following mixtures will taste the same as Super Salad Dressing?**

options.content: $80\text{ mL}$ of oil with $30\text { mL}$ of vinegar
$3\text{ mL}$ of oil with $8\text { mL}$ of vinegar
$56\text{ mL}$ of oil with $21\text { mL}$ of vinegar
$40\text{ mL}$ of oil with $25\text { mL}$ of vinegar
$48\text{ mL}$ of oil with $18\text { mL}$ of vinegar

hints.content: The mixture will have the same taste if the ratio of oil to vinegar  is equivalent to $8:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Oil ($\text{mL}$) | $8$ | $\stackrel{\times 6}\rightarrow$ | $48$ Vinegar ($\text{mL})$ | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 6}\rightarrow$  | $18$  If the mixture has $6$ times as much oil, it also needs $6$ times as much vinegar.  $48:18$ is equivalent to $8:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Oil ($\text{mL}$) | $8$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$ | $56$ Vinegar ($\text{mL})$ | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$  | $21$  If the mixture has $7$ times as much oil, it also needs $7$ times as much vinegar.  $56:21$ is equivalent to $8:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Oil ($\text{mL}$) | $8$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$ | $80$ Vinegar ($\text{mL})$ | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$  | $30$  If the mixture has $10$ times as much oil, it also needs $10$ times as much vinegar.  $80:30$ is equivalent to $8:3$.

The following mixtures will taste the same as Super Salad Dressing:  - $48\text{ mL}$ of oil with $18\text { mL}$ of vinegar - $56\text{ mL}$ of oil with $21\text { mL}$ of vinegar - $80\text{ mL}$ of oil with $30\text { mL}$ of vinegar

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: A gray crayon is  made with $5\text{ mL}$ of black wax for every $6\text{ mL}$ of white wax.    **Which of the following wax mixtures will create the same shade of gray?**

options.content: $10\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $24\text { mL}$ of white wax
$15\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $18\text { mL}$ of white wax
$35\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $42\text { mL}$ of white wax
$20\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $26\text { mL}$ of white wax
$45\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $48\text { mL}$ of white wax

hints.content: The wax mixture will create the same shade of gray if the ratio of black to white paint is equivalent to $5:6$.

||| -|-|-|- Black wax ($\text{mL}$) | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$ | $15$ White wax ($\text{mL})$ | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$  | $18$  If the mixture has $3$ times as much black wax, it also needs $3$ times as much white wax.  $15:18$ is equivalent to $5:6$.

||| -|-|-|- Black wax ($\text{mL}$) | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$ | $35$ White wax ($\text{mL})$ | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$  | $42$  If the mixture has $7$ times as much black wax, it also needs $7$ times as much white wax.  $35:42$ is equivalent to $5:6$.
The following mixtures will create the same shade of gray:  - $15\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $18\text { mL}$ of white wax - $35\text{ mL}$ of black wax mixed with $42\text { mL}$ of white wax

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Flaming BBQ Restaurant makes a dipping sauce with $9\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce for every $6$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce.    **Which of the following mixtures will taste the same as Flaming BBQ's dipping sauce?**

options.content: $6\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $10$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce
$3\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $2$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce
$45\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $30$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce
$24\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $18$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce
$12\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $8$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce

hints.content: The mixture will have the same taste if the ratio of hot sauce to barbecue sauce is equivalent to $9:6$.

||| -|-|-|- Hot sauce ($\text{mL}$) | $9$ | $\stackrel{\div 3}\rightarrow$ | $3$ Barbecue sauce ($\text{mL})$ | $6$ | $\stackrel{\div 3}\rightarrow$  | $2$  If the mixture has a third of the amount of hot sauce, it also needs a third of the amount of barbecue sauce.  $3:2$ is equivalent to $9:6$.

||| -|-|-|- Hot sauce ($\text{mL}$) | $9$ | $\stackrel{\times 1\frac{1}{3}}\rightarrow$ | $12$ Barbecue sauce ($\text{mL})$ | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 1\frac{1}{3}}\rightarrow$  | $8$  If the mixture has $1\dfrac13$ times as much hot sauce, it also needs $1\dfrac13$ times as much barbecue sauce.  $12:8$ is equivalent to $9:6$.

||| -|-|-|- Hot sauce ($\text{mL}$) | $9$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$ | $45$ Barbecue sauce ($\text{mL})$ | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$  | $30$  If the mixture has $5$ times as much hot sauce, it also needs $5$ times as much barbecue sauce.  $45:30$ is equivalent to $9:6$.

The following mixtures will taste the same as Flaming BBQ's dipping sauce:  - $3\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $2$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce - $12\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $8$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce - $45\text{ mL}$ of hot sauce mixed with $30$ spoonfuls of barbecue sauce

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: A pink crayon is  made with $12\text{ mL}$ of red wax for every $5\text{ mL}$ of white wax.    **Which of the following wax mixtures will create the same shade of pink?**

options.content: $10\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $24\text { mL}$ of white wax
$48\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $12\text { mL}$ of white wax
$13\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $6\text { mL}$ of white wax
$36\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $15\text { mL}$ of white wax
$60\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $25\text { mL}$ of white wax

hints.content: The wax mixture will create the same shade of pink if the ratio of red to white paint is equivalent to $12:5$.

||| -|-|-|- Red wax ($\text{mL}$) | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$ | $36$ White wax ($\text{mL})$ | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$  | $15$  If the mixture has $3$ times as much red wax, it also needs $3$ times as much white wax.  $36:15$ is equivalent to $12:5$.

||| -|-|-|- Red wax ($\text{mL}$) | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$ | $60$ White wax ($\text{mL})$ | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$  | $25$  If the mixture has $5$ times as much red wax, it also needs $5$ times as much white wax.  $60:25$ is equivalent to $12:5$.
The following mixtures will create the same shade of pink:  - $36\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $15\text { mL}$ of white wax - $60\text{ mL}$ of red wax mixed with $25\text { mL}$ of white wax

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Mr. Shen likes  for his homework assignments to have $2$ addition problems for every $3$ subtraction problems.   **Which of the following homework assignments could Mr. Shen create?**

options.content: $3$ addition problems and $4$ subtraction problems
$6$ addition problems and $9$ subtraction problems
$16$ addition problems and $24$ subtraction problems
$8$ addition problems and $12$ subtraction problems
$15$ addition problems and $10$ subtraction problems

hints.content: The assignment will work if the ratio of addition problems to subtraction problems is $2:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Addition problems | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$ | $6$ Subtraction problems | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$  | $9$  If the assignment has $3$ times as many addition problems, it also needs $3$ times as many subtraction problems.  $6:9$ is equivalent to $2:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Addition problems | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times 4}\rightarrow$ | $8$ Subtraction problems | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 4}\rightarrow$  | $12$  If the assignment has $4$ times as many addition problems, it also needs $4$ times as many subtraction problems.  $8:12$ is equivalent to $2:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Addition problems | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times 8}\rightarrow$ | $16$ Subtraction problems | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 8}\rightarrow$  | $24$  If the assignment has $8$ times as many addition problems, it also needs $8$ times as many subtraction problems.  $16:24$ is equivalent to $2:3$.
The following assignments will work:  - $6$ addition problems and $9$ subtraction problems - $8$ addition problems and $12$ subtraction problems - $16$ addition problems and $24$ subtraction problems

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Julia exercises at the gym. For every $3$ minutes she spends running, she spends $5$ minutes lifting weights.  **Which of the following could be how Julia spends time at the gym?**

options.content: Run for $10$ minutes and lift weights for $12$ minutes
Run for $15$ minutes and lift weights for $25$ minutes
Run for $20$ minutes and lift weights for $30$ minutes
Run for $24$ minutes and lift weights for $48$ minutes
Run for $30$ minutes and lift weights for $50$ minutes

hints.content: Julia wants the ratio of time spent running to time spent lifting weights to be $3:5$.

||| -|-|-|- Running | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$ | $15$ Lifting | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$  | $25$  If she runs for $5$ times as long, then she also needs to lift for $5$ times as long.  $15:25$ is equivalent to $3:5$.

||| -|-|-|- Running | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$ | $30$ Lifting | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$  | $50$  If she runs for $10$ times as long, then she also needs to lift for $10$ times as long.  $30:50$ is equivalent to $3:5$.
Julia could spend time at the gym in the following ways:  - Run for $15$ minutes and lift weights for $25$ minutes - Run for $30$ minutes and lift weights for $50$ minutes

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Joseph is making kebabs. He wants each kebab to have $3$ pieces of meat and $4$ pieces of vegetables.  **Which of the following could Joseph use to make kebabs without any leftovers?**

options.content: $18$ pieces of meat and $30$ pieces of vegetables
$20$ pieces of meat and $32$ pieces of vegetables
$30$ pieces of meat and $40$ pieces of vegetables
$45$ pieces of meat and $60$ pieces of vegetables
$72$ pieces of meat and $96$ pieces of vegetables

hints.content: Joseph wants the ratio of meat pieces to vegetable pieces to be $3:4$.

||| -|-|-|- Meat | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$ | $30$ Vegetable | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 10}\rightarrow$  | $40$  If Joseph has $10$ times as many pieces of meat, then he needs $10$ times as many pieces of vegetables.  $30:40$ is equivalent to $3:4$.

||| -|-|-|- Meat | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 15}\rightarrow$ | $45$ Vegetable | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 15}\rightarrow$  | $60$  If Joseph has $15$ times as many pieces of meat, then he needs $15$ times as many pieces of vegetables.  $45:60$ is equivalent to $3:4$.

||| -|-|-|- Meat | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 24}\rightarrow$ | $72$ Vegetable | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 24}\rightarrow$  | $96$  If Joseph has $24$ times as many pieces of meat, then he needs $24$ times as many pieces of vegetables.  $72:96$ is equivalent to $3:4$.

Joseph could make kebabs with the following without any leftovers:  - $30$ pieces of meat and $40$ pieces of vegetables - $45$ pieces of meat and $60$ pieces of vegetables - $72$ pieces of meat and $96$ pieces of vegetables

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Makoto likes to eat her trail mix piece by piece. For every $5$ pieces of nuts she eats, she eats $2$ pieces of candy.  **Which of the following could be what Makoto eats from a bag of trail mix?**

options.content: $10$ pieces of nuts and $4$ pieces of candy
$15$ pieces of nuts and $12$ pieces of candy
$25$ pieces of nuts and $20$ pieces of candy
$40$ pieces of nuts and $18$ pieces of candy
$45$ pieces of nuts and $18$ pieces of candy

hints.content: The ratio of the pieces of nuts to the pieces of candy Makoto eats is $5:2$.

||| -|-|-|- Nuts | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$ | $10$ Candy | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$  | $4$  If she eats $2$ times as many pieces of nuts, then she must eat $2$ times as many pieces of candy.  $10:4$ is equivalent to $5:2$.

||| -|-|-|- Nuts | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times 9}\rightarrow$ | $45$ Candy | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times 9}\rightarrow$  | $18$  If she eats $9$ times as many pieces of nuts, then she must eat $9$ times as many pieces of candy.  $45:18$ is equivalent to $5:2$.
Makoto could eat the following from a bag of trail mix:  - $10$ pieces of nuts and $4$ pieces of candy - $45$ pieces of nuts and $18$ pieces of candy

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Tomas needs exactly $6$ potatoes to make $12$ potato pancakes.  **Which of the following statements are true?**

options.content: Tomas needs exactly $12$ potatoes to make $24$ potato pancakes.
Tomas needs exactly $18$ potatoes to make $36$ potato pancakes.
Tomas needs exactly $24$ potatoes to make $44$ potato pancakes.
Tomas needs exactly $30$ potatoes to make $60$ potato pancakes.
Tomas needs exactly $36$ potatoes to make $78$ potato pancakes.

hints.content: The ratio of potatoes to potato pancakes is $6:12$.

||| -|-|-|- Potatoes | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$ | $12$ Pancakes | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$  | $24$  If Tomas uses $2$ times as many potatoes, then he can make $2$ times as many potato pancakes.  $12:24$ is equivalent to $6:12$.

||| -|-|-|- Potatoes | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$ | $18$ Pancakes | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$  | $36$  If Tomas uses $3$ times as many potatoes, then he can make $3$ times as many potato pancakes.  $18:36$ is equivalent to $6:12$.

||| -|-|-|- Potatoes | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$ | $30$ Pancakes | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times 5}\rightarrow$  | $60$  If Tomas uses $5$ times as many potatoes, then he can make $5$ times as many potato pancakes.  $30:60$ is equivalent to $6:12$.

The following statements are true:  - Tomas needs exactly $12$ potatoes to make $24$ potato pancakes. - Tomas needs exactly $18$ potatoes to make $36$ potato pancakes. - Tomas needs exactly $30$ potatoes to make $60$ potato pancakes.

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: Peter is a beekeeper who sells jars of honey and honeycombs at the market. For every $10$ jars of honey he brings to the market, he brings $3$ honeycombs.  **Which of the following could be what Peter brings to the market?**

options.content: $18$ jars of honey and $5$ honeycombs
$20$ jars of honey and $6$ honeycombs
$30$ jars of honey and $9$ honeycombs
$40$ jars of honey and $10$ honeycombs
$60$ jars of honey and $16$ honeycombs

hints.content: The ratio of jars of honey to number of honeycombs Peter brings to the market is $10:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Jars | $10$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$ | $20$ Honeycombs | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$  | $6$  If Peter brings $2$ times as many jars of honey to the market, then he needs to bring $2$ times as many honeycombs as well.   $20:6$ is equivalent to $10:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Jars | $10$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$ | $30$ Honeycombs | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 3}\rightarrow$  | $9$  If Peter brings $3$ times as many jars of honey to the market, then he needs to bring $3$ times as many honeycombs as well.   $30:9$ is equivalent to $10:3$.
The following could be what Peter brings to the market:  - $20$ jars of honey and $6$ honeycombs - $30$ jars of honey and $9$ honeycombs

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4

question.content: For every $3$ days of vacation, Farah packs $4$ outfits.  **Which of the following statements are true?**

options.content: Farah would pack $6$ outfits for an $8$-day vacation.
Farah would pack $8$ outfits for a $6$-day vacation.
Farah would pack $10$ outfits for a $9$-day vacation.
Farah would pack $16$ outfits for a $12$-day vacation.
Farah would pack $28$ outfits for a $21$-day vacation.

hints.content: For Farah, the ratio of the number of outfits to the length of the vacation in days is $4:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Outfits | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$ | $8$ Days | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 2}\rightarrow$  | $6$  If Farah goes on a vacation that is $2$ times as long, then she would pack $2$ times as many outfits.  $8:6$ is equivalent to $4:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Outfits | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 4}\rightarrow$ | $16$ Days | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 4}\rightarrow$  | $12$  If Farah goes on a vacation that is $4$ times as long, then she would pack $4$ times as many outfits.  $16:12$ is equivalent to $4:3$.

||| -|-|-|- Outfits | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$ | $28$ Days | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times 7}\rightarrow$  | $21$  If Farah goes on a vacation that is $7$ times as long, then she would pack $7$ times as many outfits.  $28:21$ is equivalent to $4:3$.

The following statements are true:  - Farah would pack $8$ outfits for a $6$-day vacation. - Farah would pack $16$ outfits for a $12$-day vacation. - Farah would pack $28$ outfits for a $21$-day vacation.

item.problemType: MS - "equivalent ratios in the real world" 6.2.4
